heisig_story: The two directions, above and below, are usually pointed at with the finger. But the characters do not follow that custom, so we have to choose something else, easily remembered. The primitives show a magic wand standing above a floor - "magically," you might say. Anyway, go right on to the next frame, since the two belong together and are best remembered as a unit, just as the words above and below suggest each other.

WaniKani_Meaning_Mnemonic: You find a toe on the ground. It's weird, because it's above the ground, not where toes belong.
WaniKani_Meaning_Info: Focus your imagination on how body parts should be buried, not above ground like this. Sure, finding a toe is a little strange, but finding a toe above the ground? Downright silly.
WaniKani_Reading_Mnemonic: Of course when you find a toe above the ground, you want to know where the toe came from. When you examine it, you see a name written on there. This toe belongs to the local clumsy farmhand, Jourm (ã˜ã‚‡ã†).
WaniKani_Reading_Info:
Try to remember Jourm, the local farmhand. He is a recurring character that will come up anytime the reading for a kanji is ã˜ã‚‡ã†.
He is a very big man, and he wears farmer's clothes. It's important to imagine your version of Jourm as very big, because it will help us to differentiate him from Jo-Anne, who is the character associated with the similar, but shorter reading (and character) ã˜ã‚‡. Although Jourm will develop as you go through all the ã˜ã‚‡ã† reading kanji, for now just imagine him as a big, kinda slow dude who works for a local farmer. Also, he only has nine or fewer toes, apparently.

chinese_mnemonics_deck__story: A magic wand mysteriously standing above the floor all by itself.
origin_of_ch_char_book: Tortoise Plastron with Divination Inscription (Jia) and Scapula Bone with Inscription (Gu) (16th-11th century BC) Kings or shamans believed they could consult the gods, through fortune telling, about all affairs of the state, and so they sought guidance regarding political and military events, economics and ceremonial needs. These writings tell the results of the fortune or prophecies told by gods. The most important of the gods was Shang Di (ä¸Šå¸), the god of Heaven. Sculpture of a Shang Dynasty Man (13th century-11th century BC)
humanum_full_description_en:
Oracle is placed on an arc with a short picture to express the meaning of " up ". Because of the inconvenience of the engraving, I changed the arc to make the horizontal painting later. "Said the text": "Shang, also high on this classical, refers to all things also are all from the Shang Shang on Zhuanwen Shang...." Duan Note change, "Wen said," the ancient text head for " two ." " Two " is written according to the oracle bone inscriptions and early gold characters, but in order to distinguish it from " xia " and the number " two ", one more vertical pen is added to write "ä¸Š" in the late Spring and Autumn Period. The Zhongshan King Pot is superimposed on the character " Shang " with the sound symbol " Shang ". In addition, the characters of the Warring States Period usually add a short horizontal painting pen at the bottom of the word "ä¸Š", and the Ejun Qizhou Festival may also add "è¾µ" to indicate that it is related to the action.

Oracle has the word "God", "Compilation" 16703: "God." On the other hand, " Up " and " Down " are opposite, which can mean God and Earth respectively. "Complete Collection" 6204 is: "Fouruo (Promise) below, but I will receive (give) ã¢ (ä½‘)", that is, the land and God will not promise, and will not grant me blessing. See " below ". Oracle bone inscriptions often have the word "Shang Jia", which is the ninth ancestor of the Shang Dynasty. "Compilation" 6384: "Send the earthwork to Shangjia", to make sacrifices to Shangjia for cutting earth. There is also the word "Shang Shi" in the oracle bone inscriptions, which is the name of some temple masters gathered by the ancestors of the Shang Dynasty (Xu Zhongshu).

" Up " and " Down " in bronze inscriptions are opposite, and are directional words, mostly referring to heaven. Such as ã¬ bell: "The first king is stern and talented (in)", which means that the first king was respectfully in the sky. It also refers to the god of heaven and earth (Shirakawa Jing) by "Xia Shang". For example, Cai Houpan: "Xia Xia Zhi No" refers to the praise and derogation of the gods of heaven and earth, "The Analects. "Shu Er" also has the saying "up and down gods". The word "God" is also commonly used in bronze inscriptions, such as the historical wall plate: "God surrenders good virtues and great spirits (screen)", which refers to the beautiful virtues and vast assistance of God. In addition, the inscription has the word "ã ¯(Yi) Shang", which means more than, and the new Qihu Talisman: "If you use five thousand soldiers, you must know the King Fu and dare to do it." "Shangpang" (the vassal state in the Spring and Autumn Period), the place name "Shangluo" (the place name of the Western Zhou Dynasty), "Shangle" (Warring States Weidi), "Shangjun" (Qindi), all use the word "ä¸Š" with the word.

The primitives show a magic wand standing above a floor - "magically," you might say. Anyway, go right on to the next frame, since the two belong together and are best remembered as a unit, just as the words above and below suggest each other.

Meaning Mnemonic
You find a toe on the ground. It's weird, because it's above the ground, not where toes belong.
Focus your imagination on how body parts should be buried, not above ground like this. Sure, finding a toe is a little strange, but finding a toe above the ground? Downright silly.

Of course when you find a toe above the ground, you want to know where the toe came from. When you examine it, you see a name written on there. This toe belongs to the local clumsy farmhand, Jourm (ã˜ã‚‡ã†).
